title: MP Charlie Elphicke, 48, pleads not guilty to three sex assaults on two women
text:
Independent MP Charlie Elphicke, 48, appeared at Southwark Crown Court in London this morning court to deny three counts of sexual assault (he is pictured outside Soutwark Crown Court today)

Independent MP Charlie Elphicke has pleaded not guilty to three counts of sexual assault against two women.

The MP for Dover, 48, is accused of a sexual assault against one woman in 2007 and two assaults against a different woman within a week of each other in 2016.

He appeared in the dock at Southwark Crown Court in London this morning, wearing a navy suit and a grey tie.

Elphicke is said to have touched both women without their consent.

After speaking to confirm his date of birth and nationality, Elphicke denied the charges of sexually touching the two women without their consent.

At a previous hearing in a lower court, the 48-year-old indicated he would give a not-guilty plea in front of a Crown Court judge.

His trial is expected to last between 10 days and three weeks and may involve at least 15 witnesses.

Judge Deborah Taylor bailed Elphicke, of St Margarets Bay, Dover, to return to Southwark Crown Court for his trial on June 29 next year.

The MP for Dover, 48, (pictured with his wife Natalie Ross leaving Southwark Crown Court today) is accused of a sexual assault against one woman in 2007 and two assaults against a different woman within a week of each other in 2016

Shortly before the end of the hearing, Judge Taylor issued a warning to the public gallery after Elphicke's defence raised comments about the case made on Twitter.

She said: 'It is not only news outlets that are subject to contempt of court rules. Members of the public who prejudge cases by posting comments on places such as Twitter or Facebook are subject too.

'Everyone should be very careful.'

Elphicke represented the Conservatives from 2010 until November 2017, when he was suspended from the party after the allegations of sexual assault were referred to the police.

He was readmitted to the party in December 2018, prior to a confidence vote in then-prime minister Theresa May.

The now-Independent MP was formally charged in July this year and was again suspended by the Tories the same day.
